EmailTemplate.subject: Turbonomic Top Ten Features #4: Workload Chart
EmailTemplate.textOnly:
Hi {{Lead.First Name}},
Here's your fourth of ten Turbonomic Top Features. Of course, if at any time you want to accelerate your learning, you can visit the Green Circle Community <[[https://greencircle.turbonomic.com/welcome?utm_source=vmturbo&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=ENG-HybridCloud&utm_content=Mid04]]> and gain tips and tricks from real Turbonomic customers and evaluators just like you. Feature #4: Workload Chart
The Workload Chart is the place in Turbonomic that answers the following question:
- What is the state of my entire virtual and physical infrastructure?
Step-By-Step: Workload Chart
The following steps will guide you through the Workload Chart:
- Rings on the Workload Chart represent groups of VMs across the environment whose Host and Datastore utilizations correspond to the position of each ring relative to the X and Y axes (in the Workload Chart, X and Y should both be considered Independent Variables). Colored arcs represent the utilization levels of the most constraining resource on subsets of VMs in each ring: Red = Critically Overutilized, Yellow = Overutilized, Green = Desired Utilization, and Blue = Underutilized. It is important to understand that although these VMs are grouped together on the Workload Chart, they do not necessarily reside close together within the environment. - Use the Gear Icon to change the Workload Chart axes - Draw a box around any of the rings in the Workload Chart to display the specific VMs, Hosts, and Datastores contained in the ring, as well as Actions associated with these entities
- Click the name of any entity in the Selected VMs window to view additional detail on utilization, resources, related entities, Actions, and the Audit Log - which will show any Actions that have been taken on the selected entity
